_link.title: I can compare the structures of plant cells and animal cells

toLevel2.question: Which structure is found in plant cells but not in animal cells?

options.text: Cell wall
Nucleus
options.explanation: Both plant and animal cells contain a nucleus.

options.text: Mitochondria
options.explanation: Both plant and animal cells contain mitochondria for cellular respiration.

options.text: Plasma membrane
options.explanation: Both plant and animal cells are surrounded by a plasma membrane.

toLevel2.question: Which organelle is found in animal cells but is absent from plant cells?

options.text: Lysosomes
Ribosomes
options.explanation: Ribosomes are found in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: The Golgi apparatus is present in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: Endoplasmic reticulum
options.explanation: Endoplasmic reticulum is found in both plant and animal cells.

toLevel2.question: Which organelle allows plant cells to carry out photosynthesis?

options.text: Chloroplasts
Mitochondria
options.explanation: Mitochondria carry out cellular respiration, not photosynthesis.

options.text: Ribosomes
options.explanation: Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis, not photosynthesis.

options.text: Vesicles
options.explanation: Vesicles transport materials within the cell but do not perform photosynthesis.

toLevel2.question: What type of vacuole is a distinguishing feature of plant cells?

options.text: A large permanent vacuole
Many small temporary vacuoles
options.explanation: Small temporary vacuoles are found in animal cells, not as a distinguishing feature of plant cells.

options.text: A vacuole that contains DNA
options.explanation: The vacuole stores water and solutes, not DNA.

options.text: A vacuole attached to the nucleus
options.explanation: The large central vacuole is not attached to the nucleus.

toLevel2.question: Which of the following organelles is shared by both plant and animal cells?

options.text: Mitochondria
Chloroplasts
options.explanation: Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells.

options.text: Cell wall
options.explanation: A cell wall is found in plant cells but not in animal cells.

options.text: Large permanent vacuole
options.explanation: A large permanent vacuole is a feature of plant cells, not animal cells.

toLevel2.statement: Animal cells have a cell wall surrounding the plasma membrane.
toLevel2.explanation: Animal cells do not have a cell wall. Only plant cells have a cell wall outside the plasma membrane.

toLevel2.statement: Both plant and animal cells contain a nucleus, ribosomes and a plasma membrane.
toLevel2.explanation: The nucleus, ribosomes and plasma membrane are organelles shared by both plant and animal cells.

toLevel2.sentence: Plant cells have a {{blank:1}}, chloroplasts and a large permanent {{blank:2}}, which are not found in animal cells.
Animal cells contain {{blank:1}} for digesting waste materials, which are not typically found in {{blank:2}} cells.
Both plant and animal cells contain a {{blank:1}}, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus and {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.question: Why do plant cells have a cell wall but animal cells do not?

options.text: The cell wall provides structural support that animals get from bones or exoskeletons instead
Animal cells are too small to need a cell wall
options.explanation: Cell size is not the reason; animals use different structures like bones for support.

options.text: Animal cells use chloroplasts for structural support instead
options.explanation: Chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis and are not found in animal cells.

options.text: The cell wall would prevent animal cells from moving
options.explanation: While rigidity can limit movement, the main reason is that animals use alternative support structures.

toLevel3.question: Why is it incorrect to say that plant cells do not have mitochondria?

options.text: Plant cells have both mitochondria and chloroplasts because they carry out both respiration and photosynthesis
Plant cells only have mitochondria when it is dark
options.explanation: Mitochondria are permanent organelles present in plant cells at all times.

options.text: Plant cells replace their mitochondria with chloroplasts as they mature
options.explanation: Mitochondria and chloroplasts serve different functions and both remain in the cell.

options.text: Plant cells have mitochondria only in their roots
options.explanation: All living plant cells contain mitochondria, not just root cells.

toLevel3.question: What is the main function of chloroplasts in plant cells?

options.text: To convert light energy into chemical energy through photosynthesis
To break down glucose for energy through respiration
options.explanation: Cellular respiration occurs in mitochondria, not chloroplasts.

options.text: To store water and maintain turgor pressure
options.explanation: Water storage and turgor pressure are functions of the large central vacuole.

options.text: To digest waste materials inside the cell
options.explanation: Digestion of waste is a function of lysosomes in animal cells.

toLevel3.question: How does the large central vacuole contribute to a plant cell's structure?

options.text: It fills with water to create turgor pressure, which helps the cell maintain its shape
It produces energy for the cell through respiration
options.explanation: Energy production occurs in mitochondria, not the vacuole.

options.text: It synthesises proteins for the cell membrane
options.explanation: Protein synthesis occurs at ribosomes, not in the vacuole.

options.text: It contains chlorophyll for photosynthesis
options.explanation: Chlorophyll is found in chloroplasts, not in the vacuole.

toLevel3.question: A student states that plant cells are completely different from animal cells. Why is this statement inaccurate?

options.text: Plant and animal cells share many organelles including the nucleus, mitochondria, ER and Golgi apparatus
Plant and animal cells are identical in every way
options.explanation: They share many organelles but have key differences such as cell walls and chloroplasts.

options.text: The only difference is that plant cells are green
options.explanation: Colour is a superficial observation; the real differences involve organelles like cell walls, chloroplasts and vacuoles.

options.text: Plant cells contain no organelles that animal cells have
options.explanation: Plant cells share many organelles with animal cells, including the nucleus and mitochondria.

toLevel3.question: Why do animal cells rely on bones or exoskeletons for support rather than a cell wall?

options.text: Animal cells lack cell walls, so the organism uses specialised tissues for structural support instead
Animal cells have cell walls but they are too thin to provide support
options.explanation: Animal cells do not have cell walls at all.

options.text: Bones are made of the same material as plant cell walls
options.explanation: Bones are made of calcium phosphate and collagen, while plant cell walls are made of cellulose.

options.text: Animal cells use their large central vacuole for support
options.explanation: Animal cells do not have a large central vacuole; this is a feature of plant cells.

toLevel3.statement: Plant cells carry out both photosynthesis and cellular respiration because they contain both chloroplasts and mitochondria.
toLevel3.explanation: Plant cells use chloroplasts for photosynthesis and mitochondria for cellular respiration.

toLevel3.sentence: The {{blank:1}} provides structural support in plant cells, whereas animals rely on structures such as {{blank:2}} for support.
A common misconception is that plant cells do not {{blank:1}}, but in fact they contain {{blank:2}} and carry out cellular respiration.
Plant cells have {{blank:1}} for photosynthesis, while both plant and animal cells have {{blank:2}} for releasing energy from glucose.

toLevel4.question: A student examines a cell under a microscope and observes a nucleus, mitochondria and lysosomes but no cell wall or chloroplasts. What type of cell is this most likely to be?

options.text: An animal cell
A plant cell
options.explanation: Plant cells have a cell wall and chloroplasts but typically lack lysosomes.

options.text: A bacterial cell
options.explanation: Bacterial cells are prokaryotes and do not have a membrane-bound nucleus or lysosomes.

options.text: A fungal cell
options.explanation: Fungal cells have a cell wall, which was not observed in this cell.

toLevel4.question: A cell is observed to have a cell wall, chloroplasts, a large central vacuole and mitochondria. What type of cell is this?

options.text: A plant cell
An animal cell
options.explanation: Animal cells lack a cell wall, chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.

options.text: A prokaryotic cell
options.explanation: Prokaryotic cells do not have chloroplasts or a membrane-bound nucleus.

options.text: A red blood cell
options.explanation: Red blood cells are animal cells and lack a nucleus, cell wall and chloroplasts.

toLevel4.question: In a comparison table, a student writes that only animal cells have a plasma membrane. Is this correct?

options.text: No, both plant and animal cells have a plasma membrane
Yes, plant cells use only their cell wall as a boundary
options.explanation: Plant cells have both a cell wall and a plasma membrane; the plasma membrane sits inside the cell wall.

options.text: Yes, the cell wall replaces the plasma membrane in plant cells
options.explanation: The cell wall does not replace the plasma membrane; both are present in plant cells.

options.text: No, only plant cells have a plasma membrane
options.explanation: Both plant and animal cells have a plasma membrane.

toLevel4.question: A researcher removes the cell wall from a plant cell. How would this affect the cell compared to a normal plant cell?

options.text: The cell would lose structural support and be more vulnerable to bursting from osmotic pressure
The cell would immediately die because the cell wall is essential for respiration
options.explanation: Respiration occurs in mitochondria, not the cell wall; the cell could survive briefly without it.

options.text: The cell would become an animal cell because it no longer has a cell wall
options.explanation: Removing the cell wall does not change the cell type; the cell still has chloroplasts and a large vacuole.

options.text: The cell would not be affected because the plasma membrane provides all necessary support
options.explanation: The plasma membrane alone cannot withstand osmotic pressure; the cell wall is needed for structural support.

toLevel4.question: A student is asked to draw and label a plant cell for an exam. Which organelles must be included that would NOT appear in an animal cell diagram?

options.text: Cell wall, chloroplasts and large central vacuole
Nucleus, mitochondria and ribosomes
options.explanation: These organelles are found in both plant and animal cells.

options.text: Lysosomes, vesicles and Golgi apparatus
options.explanation: Lysosomes are found in animal cells, and vesicles and Golgi apparatus are in both cell types.

options.text: Endoplasmic reticulum, plasma membrane and vesicles
options.explanation: These organelles are shared by both plant and animal cells.

toLevel4.question: During a practical, a student places a plant cell and an animal cell in pure water. Which cell is more likely to burst and why?

options.text: The animal cell, because it lacks a cell wall to resist the inward flow of water
The plant cell, because its vacuole absorbs too much water
options.explanation: The plant cell's cell wall provides structural resistance against bursting from osmotic pressure.

options.text: Both cells would burst equally quickly
options.explanation: The plant cell is protected by its cell wall, while the animal cell has no such protection.

options.text: Neither cell would be affected by pure water
options.explanation: Pure water is hypotonic to cells, causing water to move in by osmosis.

toLevel4.question: An exam question asks a student to compare plant and animal cells. Which response uses correct comparative language?

options.text: Plant cells have a cell wall, whereas animal cells do not
Plant cells are better than animal cells because they have more organelles
options.explanation: Comparative biology does not rank cell types as better or worse; it identifies structural differences.

options.text: Animal cells have everything that plant cells have plus lysosomes
options.explanation: Animal cells lack cell walls, chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.

options.text: Plant cells do not contain any of the organelles found in animal cells
options.explanation: Plant and animal cells share many organelles including the nucleus, mitochondria and ribosomes.

toLevel4.sentence: A cell observed under a microscope has a nucleus and mitochondria but no {{blank:1}} or chloroplasts, so it is most likely an {{blank:2}} cell.
When placed in pure water, an animal cell may {{blank:1}} because it lacks a {{blank:2}} to resist the inward flow of water.
In a comparison table, a student should list {{blank:1}}, chloroplasts and a large central vacuole as structures found only in {{blank:2}} cells.

toLevel5.question: A student claims that because plant cells have chloroplasts, they do not need mitochondria. Analyse this claim.

options.text: This is incorrect because chloroplasts produce glucose, but mitochondria are still needed to release energy from it through respiration
This is correct because photosynthesis provides all the energy a plant cell needs
options.explanation: Photosynthesis produces glucose, but cells need mitochondria to convert glucose into usable energy (ATP).

options.text: This is correct because chloroplasts and mitochondria perform the same function
options.explanation: Chloroplasts carry out photosynthesis while mitochondria carry out cellular respiration; these are different processes.

options.text: This is incorrect because mitochondria carry out photosynthesis at night
options.explanation: Mitochondria carry out respiration, not photosynthesis, regardless of the time of day.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the statement: 'The only structural difference between plant and animal cells is the presence of a cell wall.'

options.text: This is an oversimplification because plant cells also have chloroplasts and a large central vacuole that animal cells lack
This is completely correct and there are no other differences
options.explanation: Plant cells also uniquely have chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.

options.text: This is incorrect because animal cells also have a cell wall
options.explanation: Animal cells do not have a cell wall; that is a genuine difference.

options.text: This is correct for mature cells but not for young cells
options.explanation: The differences in organelles apply to both mature and young cells.

toLevel5.question: Root cells in plants typically lack chloroplasts. What does this suggest about the relationship between cell structure and function?

options.text: Cells only contain organelles that are relevant to their specific function, so root cells lack chloroplasts because they do not receive light for photosynthesis
Root cells are actually animal cells growing underground
options.explanation: Root cells are plant cells; they have a cell wall and other plant features but lack chloroplasts.

options.text: Root cells do not need energy because they are underground
options.explanation: Root cells still need energy for growth and transport; they obtain it through respiration using mitochondria.

options.text: All plant cells must have chloroplasts to be classified as plant cells
options.explanation: Not all plant cells have chloroplasts; root cells and some other specialised cells lack them.

toLevel5.question: A textbook states that lysosomes are found exclusively in animal cells. A student finds research showing that some plant cells may contain lysosome-like structures. How should the student interpret this?

options.text: Scientific understanding can be refined as new evidence emerges, and the textbook presents a simplified model
The research must be wrong because textbooks are always completely accurate
options.explanation: Textbooks present simplified models that can be updated as new research emerges.

options.text: The student should ignore the research and only follow the textbook
options.explanation: Students should consider new evidence while understanding that textbooks provide useful general models.

options.text: This means plant and animal cells are actually identical
options.explanation: Finding lysosome-like structures in some plant cells does not eliminate other structural differences.

toLevel5.question: Why is it important to use comparative language such as 'whereas' and 'in contrast' when comparing plant and animal cells in VCE assessments?

options.text: It clearly highlights the differences and shows the examiner that you can directly compare structures
It makes the answer longer and therefore worth more marks
options.explanation: Answer length does not determine marks; clarity and accuracy of comparisons do.

options.text: It is a grammatical requirement for all biology answers
options.explanation: Comparative language is specifically important for comparison questions, not all biology answers.

options.text: It is not important; listing features separately is equally effective
options.explanation: Listing features separately does not demonstrate the ability to directly compare, which is what comparison questions assess.

toLevel5.question: A diagram shows a cell with a nucleus, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, ribosomes and vesicles, but no cell wall, chloroplasts or large vacuole. A student identifies it as a plant cell. What error has the student made?

options.text: The student has overlooked the absence of plant-specific structures like the cell wall and chloroplasts
The student is correct because the cell has a nucleus
options.explanation: Having a nucleus makes it a eukaryotic cell but does not distinguish plant from animal.

options.text: The student is correct because the cell has mitochondria
options.explanation: Both plant and animal cells contain mitochondria.

options.text: The student should have identified it as a prokaryote
options.explanation: The cell has a membrane-bound nucleus, so it is a eukaryote, not a prokaryote.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the claim: 'Animal cells are simpler than plant cells because they have fewer types of organelles.'

options.text: This is misleading because animal cells have lysosomes that plant cells lack, so the difference is in which organelles are present, not overall complexity
This is correct because plant cells have three extra organelles
options.explanation: While plant cells have unique organelles, animal cells also have lysosomes, so the comparison is not simply about having more or fewer.

options.text: This is correct because animal cells have no unique organelles
options.explanation: Animal cells have lysosomes, which are not typically found in plant cells.

options.text: This is incorrect because animal cells have more organelles than plant cells
options.explanation: Neither cell type is universally more complex; they have different organelles suited to different functions.

toLevel5.question: A student suggests that removing chloroplasts from a plant cell would make it identical to an animal cell. Evaluate this suggestion.

options.text: This is incorrect because the plant cell would still have a cell wall and large central vacuole, which animal cells lack
This is correct because chloroplasts are the only difference between plant and animal cells
options.explanation: Plant cells also differ from animal cells in having a cell wall and large central vacuole.

options.text: This is correct because removing chloroplasts stops photosynthesis, making the cell identical to an animal cell
options.explanation: Stopping photosynthesis does not remove the cell wall or other plant-specific features.

options.text: This is incorrect because the cell would die without chloroplasts
options.explanation: Root cells survive without chloroplasts; the issue is that other plant-specific structures remain.

toLevel5.sentence: Root cells lack {{blank:1}} because they do not receive light, but they still contain {{blank:2}} to carry out cellular respiration.
The claim that animal cells are simpler than plant cells is {{blank:1}} because animal cells have unique organelles such as {{blank:2}} that plant cells lack.
